title: 114_hr2332
content: The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under the Secretary of Transportation. Grants can be awarded to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects that significantly impact metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States, including highway and bridge projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects that will impact metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States. Eligible projects include highway and bridge projects, public transportation projects, and passenger or freight rail transportation projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects impacting metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States. Eligible projects include highway and bridge projects, public transportation projects, passenger or freight rail transportation projects, port infrastructure investments, aviation infrastructure projects, and water infrastructure projects. Coordination is required for water infrastructure projects with the EPA and the Army. The Secretary must coordinate grants for infrastructure projects with the EPA and the Army. Entities must submit applications for grants, and criteria for grant awards will be specified by the Secretary within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Within 90 days of the Act's enactment, the Secretary will issue regulations outlining criteria for competitive grants under subsection (b). Criteria will include financial commitments for proposed projects from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs assisted by these grants cannot exceed 100 percent. The Secretary will issue regulations for competitive grants under subsection (b) within 90 days of the Act's enactment, including criteria for financial commitments from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs assisted by these grants cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants under subsection (b) should be distributed equitably, address urban and rural needs, promote veteran training and employment, and ensure a percentage is spent through small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. The grant funds must comply with Title 40 requirements and Buy America provisions, ensuring that iron, steel, and manufactured goods used in projects are made in the United States, with exceptions as determined by the Secretary. Exceptions to the requirement that iron, steel, and manufactured goods used in projects must be produced in the United States include cases where it is inconsistent with the public interest, not available in sufficient quantities or quality, or if their inclusion increases project costs by more than 25 percent. The Secretary may waive the requirement for US-produced goods if it increases project costs by over 25%. Justifications for the waiver must be detailed in the Federal Register. The subsection must align with US obligations under international agreements. The Secretary must ensure grants are used efficiently and transparently. The Secretary must ensure grants are utilized efficiently and transparently, provide public information on grants, and report to Congress annually. They must also coordinate with other agencies to streamline environmental reviews for projects funded by grants. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to appropriate $985 billion for grants under the program from 2016 to 2020. 85% of the funds will be used for projects in subsection (c)(1)(A), (B), or (C), while 2% will be allocated for projects in subsection (c)(1)(D). 2% of the funds will be used for projects in subsection (c)(1)(D), while 4% will be allocated for projects in subsection (c)(1)(E), and 9% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(F). The Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary may issue bonds up to $300 billion with specific terms and conditions. Proceeds from these bonds will be made available to the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Transportation may use the proceeds from bonds issued by the Treasury Secretary to carry out the program established under the Act. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
